name: Cefazolin
cautions: Contraindicated in patients with a history of severe immediate hypersensitivity (e.g., anaphylaxis) to cefazolin or other cephalosporins.
Use with caution in patients with a history of severe penicillin allergy; cross-reactivity risk is low but not zero.
Adjust dose in renal impairment; cefazolin is primarily renally excreted.
Prolonged use may lead to overgrowth of non-susceptible organisms (e.g., C. difficile).
IV administration can cause phlebitis; monitor IV site.
Use caution in neonates and preterm infants; dosing and monitoring must follow pediatric guidelines.

compatibility.iv: Typically reconstituted and diluted in NS or D5W; compatible with common surgical prophylaxis infusions. Y-site compatibility must be confirmed with institutional references, especially when co-administered with other antibiotics.
compatibility.im: Can be given deep IM injection, often reconstituted with lidocaine for pain reduction per protocol.
compatibility.other: Avoid mixing with solutions containing calcium in the same line without verifying compatibility.

indications: Perioperative prophylaxis for many surgical procedures.
Skin and soft tissue infections due to susceptible organisms.
Bone and joint infections (e.g., osteomyelitis) caused by susceptible gram-positive organisms.
Certain bloodstream infections and endocarditis when organism is susceptible.

summary: Cefazolin is a first-generation cephalosporin widely used for surgical prophylaxis and treatment of infections caused by susceptible gram-positive bacteria. Nursing care focuses on allergy assessment (including penicillin history), monitoring for signs of hypersensitivity or C. difficile infection, and watching IV sites for phlebitis or infiltration.
